properties.Title: Advisory Alert - Covid-19 Extraordinary Voting
properties.Summary:
Description: Due to COVID-19 activity in the Peter Ballantyne First Nation communities, in-person advance and election day polls cannot be held safely for the provincial general election. Extraordinary voting will be offered to residents of these communities.
Expires: 2020-10-25T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-10-18T16:58:52-06:00, F224D078-40F0-7E87-548A-3712C1EBF734
Area: Southend, Deschambault Lake, Pelican Narrows, Sandy Bay, Amisk Lake (does not include Denare Beach), Sturgeon Landing, and Kinoosao
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A Pacific low pressure system will approach the North Coast this afternoon then track just south of Burns Lake tonight. It will bring abundant moisture across northern B.C. In favoured locations just to the north of its trajectory where cold air remains in place, this will result in heavy snow. The snow will begin this afternoon then intensify tonight. It will end early Monday morning for the Lakes District and persist through Monday afternoon for Stuart-Nechako when it will change to rain showers. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-19T09:44:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-18T17:45:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2028707063.2020
Area: Lakes District, Stuart - Nechako
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. An intense low pressure system will push northward over eastern Baffin Island bringing a mixture of heavy snow, mixed rain and snow and strong winds. Snow will begin this morning at Qikiqtarjuaq and continue until it either changes to or becomes mixed with rain some time this evening. Before this changeover, Qikiqtarjuaq will see 10 to 20 cm of snow with perhaps a few more centimetres tonight. The precipitation will end on Monday. At Pangnirtung, after the very strong east to northeast winds settle down later today, snow will begin late this evening or overnight and continue into Monday morning with 10 to 15 cm likely. On Monday the snow there is expected to either change to or become mixed with rain. At Clyde River, snow will begin this evening and continue through Monday with totals of 20 to 30 cm forecast. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-19T00:31:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-18T08:32:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1396253565.2020
Area: Clyde River, Qikiqtarjuaq, Pangnirtung
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Lake Winnipeg North Basin snow squall activity continues, as cold northwest winds blow over the relatively warm waters of the lake. These squalls are occurring southeastward off the lake, primarily into the Berens River and Bloodvein areas. The snow squalls will persist through the night and into Monday before tapering off. Snowfall accumulations will be highly variable across short distances, but accumulations of 15 cm in 12 hours will be possible and some areas may see event total snowfalls as high as 25 to 35 cm by the time it tapers off on Monday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-19T12:17:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-18T20:18:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0617207655.2020
Area: Berens River, Bloodvein
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: westerly gusts to 100 km/h. Locations: Nain and vicinity. Time span: this afternoon. Remarks: Winds will diminish below warning criteria early this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-10-18T23:59:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-18T16:49:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3866049707.2020
Area: Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. An intense low pressure system will push northward over eastern Baffin Island bringing a mixture of heavy snow, rain mixed with snow, and strong winds. As of 2 p.m. Iqaluit has reported 15 cm of snow has fallen since last night. Snow will continue to accumulate through the evening with an additional 2 to 4 cm likely before the snow tapers off overnight. Snow began this morning at Qikiqtarjuaq, with webcams showing accumulating snow throughout the day. Snow will taper off overnight with an additional 5 cm of snow expected to fall overnight. At Pangnirtung, gusty northeasterly winds will subside this evening before switching to the southwest. As winds switch to the southwest, temperatures will drop and the rain will transition to snow. Snow will continue through Monday, and by Monday afternoon, 10 to 15 cm of snow is likely; snow will taper off Monday evening. At Clyde River, snow will begin this evening and continue through Monday with totals of 20 to 30 cm forecast. Snow will begin overnight in Igloolik and Sanirajak and continue through Monday and Monday night with a total of 10 to 15 cm expected. Snow will taper off Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-19T11:26:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-18T19:27:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0842585255.2020
Area: Hall Beach, Igloolik, Clyde River, Qikiqtarjuaq, Pangnirtung, Iqaluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. An intense low pressure system will push northward over eastern Baffin Island bringing a mixture of heavy snow, mixed rain and snow and strong winds. As of 8 a.m. Iqaluit had already received 11 cm of snow, and up to 10 cm more will likely fall before the snow tapers off this evening. Snow began this morning at Qikiqtarjuaq and will continue until it either changes to or becomes mixed with rain some time this evening. Before this changeover, Qikiqtarjuaq will see 10 to 15 cm of snow with perhaps a few more centimetres tonight. The precipitation will end on Monday. At Pangnirtung, after the very strong east to northeast winds settle down later today, snow will begin late this evening or overnight and continue into Monday morning with 10 to 15 cm likely. On Monday the snow there is expected to either change to or become mixed with rain. At Clyde River, snow will begin this evening and continue through Monday with totals of 20 to 30 cm forecast. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-19T06:08:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-18T14:09:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0907209205.2020
Area: Clyde River, Qikiqtarjuaq, Pangnirtung, Iqaluit
